performed_via_github_app.description:
SonarQube Cloud (formerly SonarCloud) is a SaaS code analysis tool designed to detect coding issues in 30+ languages, frameworks, and IaC platforms.Your code is checked against an extensive set of rules that cover many attributes of code, such as maintainability, reliability, and security issues, on each merge/pull request.

SonarQube Cloud integrates seamlessly into your GitHub workflow and provides clear guidance for resolving any code quality and security issues detected. The majority of popular languages can be analyzed automatically; no configuration is required!

With [SonarQube Cloud](https://sonarcloud.io/github), you get:

-   Fast, precise static analysis and feedback on your code
    
-   Support for popular languages, frameworks, and IaC tools
    
-   Free analysis for open-source projects and private projects up to max 50k LoC
    
-   Automatic analysis of pull requests and branches with results reported inline
    
-   IDE Support with [SonarQube for IDE](https://www.sonarsource.com/products/sonarlint/) integration
    
-   Quality Gate (added as a GitHub check) acting at two different levels - first, preventing you from merging pull requests that contain issues - and later, helping you to release only clean, safe code
    
-   Sign up for SonarQube free tier and begin scanning your private and public repositories
    

A [GitHub Action](https://github.com/marketplace/actions/sonarcloud-scan) is available in the marketplace to make it easy for you (for projects where automatic analysis isn't available). SonarQube Cloud also integrates smoothly with Jenkins, CircleCI, TravisCI, CirrusCI, and many other tools.

A free tier is available that allows you to explore the benefits of SonarQube Cloud using your public and private repositories. We also provide a no-commitment, [14-day trial](https://www.sonarsource.com/products/sonarcloud/signup/) of SonarQube Cloud Team for unlimited team members, up to 1.9M LoC, AI CodeFix recommendations, and more. No need to speak with a sales rep or request a license key - get automatic code analysis results on your private projects in minutes! Want to see more examples of SonarCloud in action? body: Have you ever used scripts or something else to find all tests that do not contain `checkNull`?

> Have you ever used scripts or something else to find all tests that do not contain `checkNull`?

Yes, but it is mainly done manually, and it is explained in jira that some functions do not need to add checknull, such as map and array.

thanks

I noticed that currently there is `FunctionAlias` for parameterized tests however there is no junit parameterized tests using it, is it intentional?

> thanks
> 
> I noticed that currently there is `FunctionAlias` for parameterized tests however there is no junit parameterized tests using it, is it intentional?

@snuyanzin Julian suggested still giving each operator its own test method and then having aliases use a common method for general tests. I think this makes it a bit more readable and makes it easier to add tests for a specific alias should the need arise. What do you think?

ok, thanks for clarification
then I think we don't need a javadoc
```java
/** Contains alias data for parameterized tests. */
```
or at least need to change it since it's talking about non existing parameterized tests
@chucheng92 can you please rebase and I guess it's better to bump to 1.19.3
@snuyanzin addressed your comment in latest commit

There should be an auxiliary call 'RexNode transform(RexCall call, SqlDialect targetDialect)'. For a given operator, it should look for an equivalent operator that is avaialble in the target dialect, and convert the call into a call to the new operator.

Some operators - e.g. DATEDIFF - would permute the operands.

The BiMap is a nice idea, but I think it might run out of steam. I would have one map, and a 'registerBijection' method that would put two entries into the map, one for each target dialect.

I initially wanted to support timezone, but according to my tests, there seems to be no unified standard for timezone.
Don't Merge


    Support CC format format and add tests (pg)
    Consider supporting timezone,
    full lower case day name(day) pg
    lower case day name(dy) pg

body:
I think "RelMetadataQuery should regard single-row relational expressions as unique" would be a better title than "Make single-row rels unique".

They don't need to be made unique; they are already unique, they just need to be recognized as such.
I have changed the descriptions of the SAFE_* functions to say: `Arguments are implicitly cast to one of the types BIGINT, DOUBLE, or DECIMAL`. I hope this is more precise.
@tanclary Sorry for the typo, fixed it.
Added an extra bit about not needing to thank committers.
I will close this PR. The issue is real, but there are workarounds that involve some effort, such as writing operator tests for Babel operators in different test files.

body: I have merged, then cancelled the associated commit, since the change is still under debate in JIRA.
The discussion in the JIRA is about the behavior in the presence of exceptions. It seems that this improvement may cause a different exception to be thrown.
Apparently there is no way to reopen a merged PR, so please open a new one if there is an alternate fix.

> After @snuyanzin's comment I feel we need to get to the bottom of the test issue before merging, therefore marking the PR as "request changes" until clarified

I have made the fixes you suggested. The tests should be run from the class CalciteSqlOperatorTest to exercise the evaluator.
I have no further comments. Please squash the commits so we can merge this PR. Thank you for the improvements!

Hi @adamkennedy, @libenchao , @chunweilei  and others.
I'm continuing the work on this PR at #3632.

(That PR has the unit test and is rebased on main).
@libenchao @chunweilei
Should this PR be closed?

> Should this PR be closed?

Yes, please do.
Closed in favor of https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/3632
There are some style violations

> There are some style violations

Thanks. Should be correct now.

@jduo Thanks for your PR.

Just minor suggestion:
1. Commit message should start with `[CALCITE-5647]`.
2. We like adding Java Document and JIRA link before unit test.

Thanks @JiajunBernoulli.

Do you mean I should squash my commits and give it the [CALCITE-5647] prefix?

> Apparently there is no way to reopen a merged PR, so please open a new one if there is an alternate fix.

OK，I would open a new one

Does CI stability failed?
https://github.com/apache/calcite/actions/runs/7549299627/attempts/1?pr=3631

@jduo Yes, you can `squash` after any committer approve.

But now we maybe need some new commits to make PR better.

@JiajunBernoulli I'm not sure the label "LGTM-will-merge-soon" should be added by the author. Generally the PRs should be reviewed by peers. To find a reviewer, you can ask for review in the Jira/PR/dev@ML. Fails all those approaches, and you are confident with your changes, you can commit it since you have commit privileges.

Done. Thanks for review.

> Can you consider reusing existing code as much as possible?

I don't think so, I think the real problem is that exploratory replacements have not been undo, so I fix it, this is not a workaround.

> > After @snuyanzin's comment I feel we need to get to the bottom of the test issue before merging, therefore marking the PR as "request changes" until clarified
> 
> I have made the fixes you suggested. The tests should be run from the class CalciteSqlOperatorTest to exercise the evaluator.

Thanks Mihai, the changes and the patch LGTM, can you please address the Sonar violation regarding the repeated occurrence of the string `".* out of range"`? (just define it once at the beginning of the test for better maintainability in case the error messages changes).

PS: please don't force-push while the review process is still on-going, it makes reviewers' life more difficult for not much gain, thanks!

> @jduo Thanks for your PR.
> 
> Just minor suggestion:
> 
> 1. Commit message should start with `[CALCITE-5647]`.

Done.
Seems that the "Error Prone" check is unhappy.
@rubenada @zoudan @libenchao @adamkennedy
@rubenada @zoudan @libenchao @adamkennedy , I'm completing this PR in #3634 . Please close this one.

> > @adamkennedy could you please take a look at the checkStyle violations?
> 
> Sure. This is my first attempt to contribute so I was expecting some issues.

Done in #3634.
This PR is #3154 with open comments resolved and rebased on the current main.

It looks like many unrelated tests are failing, and it's probably because reporting row counts has the side effect of altering join orderings. I'm thinking to deal with this we conditionally enable row count statistics on tables.
